It is important to complete a general questionnaire on planning life because some of the questions here will be used by your local government in making decisions about your community.

If you are unable to answer any question, please mark "N/A" (not applicable) or "NA" (not applicable) on the line provided.

This questionnaire is intended to provide information to facilitate the planning process.

If someone else answers the questions, they should write their name on each answer sheet.

Western Canadian Planning Office is still being calculated. If you have any questions, please call 1-800-555-1234.

Zabulon County Archives Office will be closed on Saturday, July 4th.

Please return completed questionnaires by July 15th.

Enclosure of Questionnaire

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Zabulon County Archives Office at the University of Zabulon County.

Please return your completed questionnaires by July 15th.

Zabulon County Archives Office,
University of Zabulon County,
Zabulon, Kansas.
1. Your full name: Mrs. Burdett

2. Your address: 895 Burdett (Mrs. William Howard)

3. Date: [illegible]

4. Where were you born? (Give name or place and country) Undated

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Thomas Shields (Farmer)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) April 5, 1906.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

I lived in Ont. till five years of age. Then came to Kellerman, Man. with my family in 1897. Came to Sask. in 1906.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question. If you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," etc., I was in my teens, etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My parents were poor in Ont. and lived in a farm-thus, in Manitoba we lived in farm. My father worked on the Railroad as station man. He kept the farm up when times were hard. Then after 1904, he bought land and built a house on the farm, 40 miles north of Brooks. He lived there until his death.

In 1906 about the time I went here 1893, the railroad had started coming west. It brought a pan into Sask. My father felt relatives on the coast and he + my mother had a great urge to see the wide open spaces of the quilt westward as they were then called. My father came west in 1894, working much of the way. He was so sure the west held a promise of a better life for him & his family, he left in 1894.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Some of them thought we were on a wild goose chase. They were no place like that. My father had to work from dawn to dark to earn a living.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family members or other people)?

My father hired me out to the homestead alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We traveled by horse-drawn carriage.

14. What incidents of the journey past do you remember? (People you met on the way, experiences with animals, adventures etc.)

We traveled until we reached the end of the road. We then had to walk.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at the stage stop. It was very cold.

16. Where did you settle or take up land to stake a claim?

We settled near the town of Strathcona.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I've lived in the town of Strathcona.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father worked on the railroad. After moving to Saskatoon, he helped build the railroad.

19. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father worked on the railroad. After moving to Saskatoon, he helped build the railroad.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Eastern Canada?

Some of them thought we were on a wild goose chase. There was no place like Ojibwe, my father had heard. We went by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other). My father tried me twice on the formalized drive.

12. What means of transportation did you use? By car, train, or boat?

We arrived in Kingston 20 miles from the border. Father bought two cars and two horses. We traveled north to find a new home.

13. What incidents of the journey most do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We traveled with friends for part of the way. People who were also going to be relocated but in another location.

14. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Western Canada?

We stayed at the Thompson Hotel full time. To get there, we took a stagecoach for the first 250 miles.

15. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Canada.

In the Badlands district, 20 miles north of Strathcona.

16. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father worked as a farmer in England, then farming to maintain his health. After moving to Canada, he helped build the first school in Eldon Park. Prior to farming, he helped build a road from Eldon Park to the townhouse. After building a road from Eldon Park to the townhouse, he farmed on the prairie.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I have three children: Ellen Radt was a teacher, who had married to a former pioneer living in Hamilton on the west farm line. Lillian Roy married a pioneer farmer living near Hamilton on the international boundary.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

This is a great change on roads. In 1906 there were only the prairie trails, but today we have paved roads, no black tails, the wires no churches, no "halls," or community halls, only the school houses which served for school.
